newsitem.title: INDIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - September 6.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - September 6.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indian business and political stories in leading newspapers prepared for Reuters by Business News and Information Services Pvt Ltd, New Delhi. Telephone: 11-3324842, 11-3761233; Fax: 91-11-3351006 Internet :

TOP STORIES
Indian Express
SETBACK FOR BHARATIYA JANATA PARTY PRESIDENT

A Delhi court ordered the framing of charges against Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) President L.K. Advani under various provisions of the Prevention of Corruption Act. The Central Bureau of Investigation has accused Advani of having accepted 3.5 million rupees in the form of a hawala (illegal money transfer) pay-off. The court order came as a severe setback for the BJP president, who had committed himself to staying out of electoral politics till the charges against him were dropped.
The Hindustan Times
FOUR JHARKHAND MUKTI MORCHA LEADERS ARRESTED IN PAY-OFF CASE

The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) arrested three former and one sitting Members of Parliament (MPs) of the Jharkhand Mukti Morcha, accused in the multi-million bribery case. CBI sources said the arrests were made following the interrogation of former Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao on his alleged involvement in the case. The four accused, while being MPs in 1993, allegedly obtained illegal gratification as a motive for voting in the Lok Sabha (Lower House of Parliament) against the no-confidence motion moved by the opposition parties. Congress president Narasimha Rao was the Prime Minister at that time.
Business Standard
TAX BREAKS TO BUOY CAPITAL MARKET

Finance Minister P. Chidambaram announced a clutch of tax concessions on investment in mutual funds, including Unit Trust of India (UTI). The move is aimed at boosting the capital markets by encouraging small investors. The minister, while replying to the budget debate, said the norms for foreign institutional investors (FIIs) had been further liberalised to permit them to raise their investments in corporate debt instruments from 30 to 100 percent. However, this would be restricted to dedicated debt funds. The minister also promised to make out a case with UTI and Life Insurance Corporation to step up their stock-market activity to ensure that FIIs alone do not emerge as the driving force in the markets.
OPPENHEIMER TO SHUT INDIAN OPERATIONS

Oppenheimer India Ltd, the local arm of the US-based Oppenheimer group, has decided to shut down operations in the country. The organisation has already retrenched staff at the Indian outfit. It would stop operations by the end of the year. However, the offshore India funds, already floated by Oppenheimer's asset management outfit, would remain operational. Sources said the decision was prompted by Oppenheimer's inability to succeed in Indian investment banking operations in the face of intense competition from other global majors.
CREDIT CAPITAL TAKEN OVER BY INFRASTRUCTURE LEASING

Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services has virtually taken over Credit Capital Venture Fund (India) Ltd by acquiring a 9.8 percent stake in the fund. It will make an open offer to acquire 20 percent of the outstanding share capital. This is first takeover bid after the announcement of the draft takeover code. It is also the first takeover of any asset management company in the country.
STATE BANK TO PUMP 500 MLN RUPEES INTO NEW SUBSIDIARY

The State Bank India (SBI) is planning to pump in 500 million rupees into the equity of SBI Commercial & International Bank Ltd (SBICIB). The SBICIB is the recast form of the erstwhile Bank of Credit & Commercial International, Bombay, which the SBI took over in 1994. The largest financial intermediary in the country has also become the first commercial bank to seek-in-principle approval of the Reserve Bank of India to float a new subsidiary to do business in the insurance sector.
Financial Express
MEASURES FAIL TO CHEER UP STOCK MARKET

The sops announced by Finance Minister P. Chidambaram for the capital market failed to shore up the general sentiment in the market. Market experts said they did not foresee any significant improvement in share prices when the stock markets would re-open on Monday. The Bombay Stock Exchange sensitive index closed at 3508.07 against the previous close of 3516.90, showing a net loss of 7.83 points. The broad-based National index, however, edged up by 4.03 points to 1581.56 from 1577.53 previously.
